Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the Chemistry Division, Kent Kirshenbaum of New York University will explore novel N-alkyl glycine oligomers, peptoids, with folding capabilities that engender unique three-dimensional structures and valuable functions. Peptoid oligomers will be synthesized to include a specific sequence of a large variety of N-substituted glycine monomer units, and a native chemical ligation strategy will be used to piece together peptoid oligomer fragments into complex sequences. Work will be performed in tandem with computational chemists in order to establish guidelines for folding peptoid macromolecules and peptide-peptoid hybrids into ordered tertiary structures. The long-term objective is to learn the rules that govern peptoid folding and to establish a predictable relationship between the sequence, the structure and the function of peptoid oligomers. The broader impacts will include training undergraduate and graduate students across the disciplines of synthetic organic chemistry, polymer chemistry, macromolecular science, and chemical biology. The project will also expand a highly successful NSF-supported science outreach effort at New York University, the Experimental Cuisine Collective. Presentations to the public will include discussing the roles of different macromolecules in diet and human health.

This research project will examine how to synthesize large molecular structures that mimic the sequence and three-dimensional structures of proteins. The development of such systems could address critical unmet needs in pharmacology and could provide new strategies for the discovery of enzyme-like catalysts. The science outreach activities will educate the public regarding the science of food and cooking, creating a venue for the discussion of chemistry principles and their influence in everyday phenomena.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project yielded significant advances in the fields of bioorganic chemistry, macromolecular chemistry, and polymer chemistry. We established important impacts in the synthesis of polymer molecules with sophisticated properties, such as the ability to fold and function in ways that mimic natural proteins. Our findings featured the experimental characterization of a promising family of polymers called “peptoids” as biomimetic molecules.

Our results demonstrated a range of promising applications for peptoid oligomers, and also will provide guidance to chemists working with other folded oligomers, or "foldamer", systems.

In the area of molecular pharmacology, our studies have established that biomimetic oligomers can be identified as potential therapeutic molecules. Peptoids may be able to exert desirable biological effects like proteins, but can be expected to be resistant to rapid degradation in the body. We have innovated methods to predict which peptoid molecules are capable of blocking protein interactions that cause disease states . Peptoids now represent an important emerging family of drug candidate compounds, and provide an opportunity to identify drugs for “undruggable” targets within the cell. In addition, our work on creating peptoid-protein hybrid structures will establish new ways to advance proteins as pharmaceuticals with enhanced specificity and stability within the body.

We discovered improved peptoids that mimic the structure and function of antimicrobial peptides. These molecules are promising candidates as future antibiotics, for which there is an urgent clinical need. Our recent efforts have helped to elucidate the mechanism of activity of our antimicrobial peptoids.

In the area of general biomedical sciences, we contributed new techniques in bioconjugate chemistry to analyze protein expression patterns from blood samples. This may lead to improved diagnostic tools for autism and other neurological diseases.

The project led to 16 published research articles in prominent scientific journals, which acknowledged the NSF-funded effort. These included prominent scientific journals, such as Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, ACS Chemical Biology, Journal of the American Chemical Society, Chemical Communications, and many more.

With regard to the broader impact of our study, we have submitted several patent applications to facilitate the commercial development of our new technologies, and we are partnering with commercial entities in the biomedical sector. Our project has provided valuable training opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students in the fields of chemistry and materials science. Our undergraduate students are acquiring fundamental laboratory skills and, more importantly, are developing a passion for additional training in the chemical sciences.
